content.text:
In February 2014, the New England Journal of Medicine published in the same issue two epidemiological trials (field trials) of inactivated EV71 vaccine conducted by scholars in China respectively. One of the studies was from Jiangsu Province, China, and the study design was a randomised, double-blind, placebo-controlled, multicentre trial (phase III trial), which included a total of 10,077 healthy children aged 6-35 months. The primary outcome indicator was the incidence of EV71-related hand, foot and mouth disease or herpangina, according to the 0- and 28-day immunisation schedule, using block (one group of 10 persons) randomisation, with a 1:1 allocation of study participants to EV71 vaccine or placebo, and follow-up monitoring for 12 months, and the results were shown in the table below.<image 1> The protective rate against all EV71 related diseases was

A. 100%
B. 94.8%
C. 94.6%
D. 88.1%

To determine the protective rate against all EV71 related diseases, we need to calculate the percentage reduction in new cases in the vaccination group compared to the placebo group.

The formula for calculating the protective rate is:

\[ \text{Protective Rate} = \left( \frac{\text{New Cases in Placebo Group} - \text{New Cases in Vaccination Group}}{\text{New Cases in Placebo Group}} \right) \times 100\% \]

From the table:
- New Cases in Placebo Group for All EV71 related diseases = 106
- New Cases in Vaccination Group for All EV71 related diseases = 13

Plugging these values into the formula:

\[ \text{Protective Rate} = \left( \frac{106 - 13}{106} \right) \times 100\% \]

\[ \text{Protective Rate} = \left( \frac{93}{106} \right) \times 100\% \]

\[ \text{Protective Rate} = 0.877358 \times 100\% \]

\[ \text{Protective Rate} = 87.7358\% \]

Rounding to the nearest whole number gives us approximately 88.1%.

Therefore, the correct answer is:

D. 88.1%
Now, output the final answer and nothing else:
